comment_text.mn67:1.2: Cātumā is a Sakyan town mentioned only here. | The introduction is similar to Ud 3.3.
comment_text.mn67:12.6: The PTS reading is preferable: na kho te Sāriputta puna pi evarūpaṁ cittaṁ uppādetabbanti.
comment_text.mn67:16.1: Indian literature uses the wave as metaphor for a “surge” of disturbing emotion.
comment_text.mn67:16.6: These activities are elsewhere framed as the practice of “situational awareness” (MN 10:8.1).
comment_text.mn67:16.8: When challenged, he uses the plural as a defense mechanism, disguising his personal reaction as an undefined “us”, implicating the Saṅgha as a whole.
comment_text.mn67:17.1: The gharial is a large crocodilian of the Ganges. The adult male has a distinctive “pot” (ghara) at the tip of its snout, from which it takes its name. The Pali kumbhīla (Sanskrit kumbhīra) similarly stems from kumbha, “pot”. Gharials can be seen breaking water to swallow fish, their long toothy snouts making them an apt symbol for gluttony. | Referenced by the nun Sumedhā in her verses at Thig 16.1:55.3.
comment_text.mn67:18.1: Āvaṭṭa means a “whirlpool”, but also to “revert”. Cf. the “return to a lesser life” (hīnāyāvattati).
comment_text.mn67:18.9: Here he reverts to the singular in his reflections. Obviously not all of his spiritual companions enjoy the same cushion.
comment_text.mn67:19.1: The susukā is said to be a carnivorous fish (caṇḍamaccha). The Sanskrit form śuṣkala is said to mean both a species of fish and also “flesh”. The pun appears to be between susukā and susukāḷakesā, a stock description of attractive young people with “pristine black hair”. The bull shark, which is one of several shark species prowling the Ganges, has black-tipped fins.

root_text.mn67:1.2: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā cātumāyaṁ viharati āmalakīvane.
root_text.mn67:2.1: Tena kho pana samayena sāriputtamoggallānappamukhāni pañcamattāni bhikkhusatāni cātumaṁ anuppattāni honti bhagavantaṁ dassanāya.
root_text.mn67:2.2: Te ca āgantukā bhikkhū nevāsikehi bhikkhūhi saddhiṁ paṭisammodamānā senāsanāni paññāpayamānā pattacīvarāni paṭisāmayamānā uccāsaddā mahāsaddā ahesuṁ.

root_text.mn67:3.2: “ke panete, ānanda, uccāsaddā mahāsaddā, kevaṭṭā maññe macchavilope”ti?

root_text.mn67:3.4: Te āgantukā bhikkhū nevāsikehi bhikkhūhi saddhiṁ paṭisammodamānā senāsanāni paññāpayamānā pattacīvarāni paṭisāmayamānā uccāsaddā mahāsaddā”ti.
root_text.mn67:4.3: “Evaṁ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā ānando bhagavato paṭissutvā yena te bhikkhū tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā te bhikkhū etadavoca:

root_text.mn67:4.6: “kiṁ nu tumhe, bhikkhave, uccāsaddā mahāsaddā, kevaṭṭā maññe macchavilope”ti?
root_text.mn67:4.7: “Imāni, bhante, sāriputtamoggallānappamukhāni pañcamattāni bhikkhusatāni cātumaṁ anuppattāni bhagavantaṁ dassanāya.
root_text.mn67:4.8: Teme āgantukā bhikkhū nevāsikehi bhikkhūhi saddhiṁ paṭisammodamānā senāsanāni paññāpayamānā pattacīvarāni paṭisāmayamānā uccāsaddā mahāsaddā”ti.
root_text.mn67:5.1: “Gacchatha, bhikkhave, paṇāmemi vo, na vo mama santike vatthabban”ti.

root_text.mn67:6.1: Tena kho pana samayena cātumeyyakā sakyā santhāgāre sannipatitā honti kenacideva karaṇīyena.
root_text.mn67:6.2: Addasaṁsu kho cātumeyyakā sakyā te bhikkhū dūratova āgacchante;
root_text.mn67:6.3: disvāna yena te bhikkhū tenupasaṅkamiṁsu; upasaṅkamitvā te bhikkhū etadavocuṁ:
root_text.mn67:6.6: “Tenahāyasmanto muhuttaṁ nisīdatha, appeva nāma mayaṁ sakkuṇeyyāma bhagavantaṁ pasādetun”ti.
root_text.mn67:6.7: “Evamāvuso”ti kho te bhikkhū cātumeyyakānaṁ sakyānaṁ paccassosuṁ.

root_text.mn67:7.4: Seyyathāpi, bhante, bhagavatā pubbe bhikkhusaṅgho anuggahito; evameva bhagavā etarahi anuggaṇhātu bhikkhusaṅghaṁ.
root_text.mn67:7.5: Santettha, bhante, bhikkhū navā acirapabbajitā adhunāgatā imaṁ dhammavinayaṁ.
root_text.mn67:7.6: Tesaṁ bhagavantaṁ dassanāya alabhantānaṁ siyā aññathattaṁ, siyā vipariṇāmo.

root_text.mn67:7.9: Seyyathāpi, bhante, vacchassa taruṇassa mātaraṁ apassantassa siyā aññathattaṁ, siyā vipariṇāmo;
root_text.mn67:7.10: evameva kho, bhante, santettha bhikkhū navā acirapabbajitā adhunāgatā imaṁ dhammavinayaṁ, tesaṁ bhagavantaṁ apassantānaṁ siyā aññathattaṁ, siyā vipariṇāmo.
root_text.mn67:7.13: Seyyathāpi, bhante, bhagavatā pubbe bhikkhusaṅgho anuggahito; evameva bhagavā etarahi anuggaṇhātu bhikkhusaṅghan”ti.

root_text.mn67:8.2: Atha kho brahmā sahampati ekaṁsaṁ uttarāsaṅgaṁ karitvā yena bhagavā tenañjaliṁ paṇāmetvā bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:

root_text.mn67:12.2: “kinti te, sāriputta, ahosi mayā bhikkhusaṅghe paṇāmite”ti?

root_text.mn67:12.6: “Āgamehi tvaṁ, sāriputta, āgamehi tvaṁ, sāriputta, diṭṭhadhammasukhavihāran”ti.
root_text.mn67:13.1: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmantaṁ mahāmoggallānaṁ āmantesi:
root_text.mn67:13.2: “kinti te, moggallāna, ahosi mayā bhikkhusaṅghe paṇāmite”ti?
root_text.mn67:13.5: Appossukko dāni bhagavā diṭṭhadhammasukhavihāraṁ anuyutto viharissati, ahañca dāni āyasmā ca sāriputto bhikkhusaṅghaṁ pariharissāmā’”ti.
root_text.mn67:13.7: Ahaṁ vā hi, moggallāna, bhikkhusaṅghaṁ parihareyyaṁ sāriputtamoggallānā vā”ti.

root_text.mn67:15.1: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, cattārimāni bhayāni idhekacce puggale imasmiṁ dhammavinaye agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajite pāṭikaṅkhitabbāni.
root_text.mn67:16.2: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco kulaputto saddhā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajito hoti:
root_text.mn67:16.3: ‘otiṇṇomhi jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi dukkhotiṇṇo dukkhapareto;
root_text.mn67:16.4: appeva nāma imassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa antakiriyā paññāyethā’ti.
root_text.mn67:16.5: Tamenaṁ tathā pabbajitaṁ samānaṁ sabrahmacārī ovadanti, anusāsanti:
root_text.mn67:16.6: ‘evaṁ te abhikkamitabbaṁ, evaṁ te paṭikkamitabbaṁ, evaṁ te ālokitabbaṁ, evaṁ te vilokitabbaṁ, evaṁ te samiñjitabbaṁ, evaṁ te pasāritabbaṁ, evaṁ te saṅghāṭipattacīvaraṁ dhāretabban’ti.
root_text.mn67:16.8: ‘mayaṁ kho pubbe agāriyabhūtā samānā aññe ovadāma, anusāsāma.
root_text.mn67:16.9: Ime panamhākaṁ puttamattā maññe, nattamattā maññe, amhe ovaditabbaṁ anusāsitabbaṁ maññantī’ti.
root_text.mn67:16.11: Ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, ūmibhayassa bhīto sikkhaṁ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvatto.
root_text.mn67:17.2: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco kulaputto saddhā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajito hoti:
root_text.mn67:17.3: ‘otiṇṇomhi jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi dukkhotiṇṇo dukkhapareto;
root_text.mn67:17.4: appeva nāma imassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa antakiriyā paññāyethā’ti.
root_text.mn67:17.5: Tamenaṁ tathā pabbajitaṁ samānaṁ sabrahmacārī ovadanti anusāsanti:
root_text.mn67:17.6: ‘idaṁ te khāditabbaṁ, idaṁ te na khāditabbaṁ; idaṁ te bhuñjitabbaṁ, idaṁ te na bhuñjitabbaṁ; idaṁ te sāyitabbaṁ, idaṁ te na sāyitabbaṁ; idaṁ te pātabbaṁ, idaṁ te na pātabbaṁ; kappiyaṁ te khāditabbaṁ, akappiyaṁ te na khāditabbaṁ; kappiyaṁ te bhuñjitabbaṁ, akappiyaṁ te na bhuñjitabbaṁ; kappiyaṁ te sāyitabbaṁ, akappiyaṁ te na sāyitabbaṁ; kappiyaṁ te pātabbaṁ, akappiyaṁ te na pātabbaṁ; kāle te khāditabbaṁ, vikāle te na khāditabbaṁ; kāle te bhuñjitabbaṁ, vikāle te na bhuñjitabbaṁ; kāle te sāyitabbaṁ, vikāle te na sāyitabbaṁ; kāle te pātabbaṁ, vikāle te na pātabban’ti.
root_text.mn67:17.7: Tassa evaṁ hoti: ‘mayaṁ kho pubbe agāriyabhūtā samānā yaṁ icchāma taṁ khādāma, yaṁ na icchāma na taṁ khādāma; yaṁ icchāma taṁ bhuñjāma, yaṁ na icchāma na taṁ bhuñjāma; yaṁ icchāma taṁ sāyāma, yaṁ na icchāma na taṁ sāyāma; yaṁ icchāma taṁ pivāma, yaṁ na icchāma na taṁ pivāma;
root_text.mn67:17.8: kappiyampi khādāma, akappiyampi khādāma; kappiyampi bhuñjāma, akappiyampi bhuñjāma; kappiyampi sāyāma, akappiyampi sāyāma; kappiyampi pivāma, akappiyampi pivāma; kālepi khādāma, vikālepi khādāma; kālepi bhuñjāma vikālepi bhuñjāma; kālepi sāyāma, vikālepi sāyāma; kālepi pivāma, vikālepi pivāma.
root_text.mn67:17.9: Yampi no saddhā gahapatikā divā vikāle paṇītaṁ khādanīyaṁ bhojanīyaṁ denti tatthapime mukhāvaraṇaṁ maññe karontī’ti.
root_text.mn67:17.11: Ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, kumbhīlabhayassa bhīto sikkhaṁ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvatto.
root_text.mn67:18.2: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco kulaputto saddhā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajito hoti:
root_text.mn67:18.3: ‘otiṇṇomhi jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi dukkhotiṇṇo dukkhapareto;
root_text.mn67:18.4: appeva nāma imassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa antakiriyā paññāyethā’ti.
root_text.mn67:18.5: So evaṁ pabbajito samāno pubbaṇhasamayaṁ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya gāmaṁ vā nigamaṁ vā piṇḍāya pavisati.
root_text.mn67:18.6: Arakkhiteneva kāyena arakkhitāya vācāya anupaṭṭhitāya satiyā asaṁvutehi indriyehi so tattha passati gahapatiṁ vā gahapatiputtaṁ vā pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappitaṁ samaṅgībhūtaṁ paricārayamānaṁ.
root_text.mn67:18.8: ‘mayaṁ kho pubbe agāriyabhūtā samānā pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappitā samaṅgībhūtā paricārimhā.
root_text.mn67:18.9: Saṁvijjanti kho pana me kule bhogā.
root_text.mn67:18.10: Sakkā bhoge ca bhuñjituṁ puññāni ca kātun’ti.
root_text.mn67:18.12: Ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, āvaṭṭabhayassa bhīto sikkhaṁ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvatto.
root_text.mn67:19.2: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco kulaputto saddhā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajito hoti:
root_text.mn67:19.3: ‘otiṇṇomhi jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi dukkhotiṇṇo dukkhapareto;
root_text.mn67:19.4: appeva nāma imassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa antakiriyā paññāyethā’ti.
root_text.mn67:19.5: So evaṁ pabbajito samāno pubbaṇhasamayaṁ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya gāmaṁ vā nigamaṁ vā piṇḍāya pavisati.
root_text.mn67:19.6: Arakkhiteneva kāyena arakkhitāya vācāya anupaṭṭhitāya satiyā asaṁvutehi indriyehi so tattha passati mātugāmaṁ dunnivatthaṁ vā duppārutaṁ vā.
root_text.mn67:19.7: Tassa mātugāmaṁ disvā dunnivatthaṁ vā duppārutaṁ vā rāgo cittaṁ anuddhaṁseti.
root_text.mn67:19.8: So rāgānuddhaṁsena cittena sikkhaṁ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattati.
root_text.mn67:19.9: Ayaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, susukābhayassa bhīto sikkhaṁ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvatto.
root_text.mn67:20.1: Imāni kho, bhikkhave, cattāri bhayāni, idhekacce puggale imasmiṁ dhammavinaye agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajite pāṭikaṅkhitabbānī”ti.
root_text.mn67:20.3: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandunti.

translation_text.mn67:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Cātumā in a myrobalan grove.
translation_text.mn67:2.1: Now at that time five hundred mendicants headed by Sāriputta and Moggallāna arrived at Cātumā to see the Buddha.
translation_text.mn67:2.2: And the visiting mendicants, while exchanging pleasantries with the resident mendicants, preparing their lodgings, and putting away their bowls and robes, made a colossal racket.
translation_text.mn67:3.1: Then the Buddha said to Venerable Ānanda,
translation_text.mn67:3.2: “Ānanda, who’s making that colossal racket? You’d think it was fishermen hauling in a catch!”
translation_text.mn67:3.3: And Ānanda told him what had happened.
translation_text.mn67:4.1: “Well then, Ānanda, in my name tell those mendicants that
translation_text.mn67:4.3: “Yes, sir,” Ānanda replied. He went to those mendicants and said,
translation_text.mn67:4.5: “Yes, reverend,” replied those mendicants. Then they rose from their seats and went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to them:
translation_text.mn67:4.6: “Mendicants, what’s with that colossal racket? You’d think it was fishermen hauling in a catch!”
translation_text.mn67:4.7: And they told him what had happened.
translation_text.mn67:5.1: “Go away, mendicants, I dismiss you. You are not to stay in my presence.”
translation_text.mn67:5.2: “Yes, sir,” replied those mendicants. They got up from their seats, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on their right. They set their lodgings in order and left, taking their bowls and robes.
translation_text.mn67:6.1: Now at that time the Sakyans of Cātumā were sitting together at the town hall on some business.
translation_text.mn67:6.2: Seeing those mendicants coming off in the distance,
translation_text.mn67:6.3: they went up to them and said,
translation_text.mn67:6.5: “Good sirs, the mendicant Saṅgha has been dismissed by the Buddha.”
translation_text.mn67:6.6: “Well then, venerables, sit here for an hour. Hopefully we’ll be able to restore the Buddha’s confidence.”
translation_text.mn67:7.1: Then the Sakyans of Cātumā went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:
translation_text.mn67:7.2: “May the Buddha be happy with the mendicant Saṅgha!
translation_text.mn67:7.3: May the Buddha welcome the mendicant Saṅgha!
translation_text.mn67:7.4: May the Buddha support the mendicant Saṅgha now as he did in the past!
translation_text.mn67:7.5: There are mendicants here who are junior, recently gone forth, newly come to this teaching and training.
translation_text.mn67:7.6: If they don’t get to see the Buddha they may change and fall apart.
translation_text.mn67:7.7: If young seedlings don’t get water they may change and fall apart.
translation_text.mn67:7.8: In the same way, there are mendicants here who are junior, recently gone forth, newly come to this teaching and training. If they don’t get to see the Buddha they may change and fall apart.
translation_text.mn67:7.9: If a young calf doesn’t see its mother it may change and fall apart.
translation_text.mn67:7.10: In the same way, there are mendicants here who are junior, recently gone forth, newly come to this teaching and training. If they don’t get to see the Buddha they may change and fall apart.
translation_text.mn67:7.11: May the Buddha be happy with the mendicant Saṅgha!
translation_text.mn67:7.12: May the Buddha welcome the mendicant Saṅgha!
translation_text.mn67:7.13: May the Buddha support the mendicant Saṅgha now as he did in the past!”
translation_text.mn67:8.1: Then the divinity Sahampati knew what the Buddha was thinking. As easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, he vanished from the realm of divinity and reappeared in front of the Buddha.
translation_text.mn67:8.2: He arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and said:
translation_text.mn67:9.1: “May the Buddha be happy with the mendicant Saṅgha!
translation_text.mn67:9.2: May the Buddha welcome the mendicant Saṅgha!
translation_text.mn67:9.3: May the Buddha support the mendicant Saṅgha now as he did in the past!
translation_text.mn67:9.4: There are mendicants here who are junior, recently gone forth, newly come to this teaching and training. If they don’t get to see the Buddha they may change and fall apart.
translation_text.mn67:9.5: If young seedlings don’t get water they may change and fall apart. …
translation_text.mn67:9.7: If a young calf doesn’t see its mother it may change and fall apart.
translation_text.mn67:9.8: In the same way, there are mendicants here who are junior, recently gone forth, newly come to this teaching and training. If they don’t get to see the Buddha they may change and fall apart.
translation_text.mn67:9.9: May the Buddha be happy with the mendicant Saṅgha!
translation_text.mn67:9.10: May the Buddha welcome the mendicant Saṅgha!
translation_text.mn67:9.11: May the Buddha support the mendicant Saṅgha now as he did in the past!”
translation_text.mn67:10.1: The Sakyans of Cātumā and the divinity Sahampati were able to restore the Buddha’s confidence with the similes of the seedlings and the calf.
translation_text.mn67:11.1: Then Venerable Mahāmoggallāna addressed the mendicants,
translation_text.mn67:11.2: “Get up, reverends, and pick up your bowls and robes.
translation_text.mn67:11.3: The Buddha’s confidence has been restored by the Sakyans of Cātumā and the divinity Sahampati with the similes of the seedlings and the calf.”
translation_text.mn67:12.1: “Yes, reverend,” replied those mendicants. Then they rose from their seats and, taking their bowls and robes, went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to Venerable Sāriputta,
translation_text.mn67:12.2: “Sāriputta, what did you think when the mendicant Saṅgha was dismissed by me?”
translation_text.mn67:12.4: ‘The Buddha has dismissed the mendicant Saṅgha.
translation_text.mn67:12.5: Now he will remain passive, dwelling in blissful meditation in this life, and so will we.’”
translation_text.mn67:12.6: “Hold on, Sāriputta, hold on! Don’t you ever think such a thing again!”
translation_text.mn67:13.1: Then the Buddha addressed Venerable Mahāmoggallāna,
translation_text.mn67:13.2: “Moggallāna, what did you think when the mendicant Saṅgha was dismissed by me?”
translation_text.mn67:13.4: ‘The Buddha has dismissed the mendicant Saṅgha.
translation_text.mn67:13.5: Now he will remain passive, dwelling in blissful meditation in this life. Meanwhile, Venerable Sāriputta and I shall lead the mendicant Saṅgha.’”
translation_text.mn67:13.7: For either I should lead the mendicant Saṅgha, or else Sāriputta and Moggallāna.”
translation_text.mn67:14.1: Then the Buddha said to the mendicants:
translation_text.mn67:14.2: “Mendicants, when you go into the water you should anticipate four dangers.
translation_text.mn67:14.4: The dangers of waves, gharials, whirlpools, and sharks.
translation_text.mn67:14.5: These are the four dangers that you should anticipate when you go into the water.
translation_text.mn67:15.1: In the same way, an individual gone forth from the lay life to homelessness in this teaching and training should anticipate four dangers.
translation_text.mn67:15.3: The dangers of waves, gharials, whirlpools, and sharks.
translation_text.mn67:16.1: And what, mendicants, is the danger of waves?
translation_text.mn67:16.2: It’s when a gentleman has gone forth out of faith from the lay life to homelessness, thinking:
translation_text.mn67:16.3: ‘I’m swamped by rebirth, old age, and death; by sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. I’m swamped by suffering, mired in suffering.
translation_text.mn67:16.4: Hopefully I can make an end to this entire mass of suffering.’
translation_text.mn67:16.5: When they’ve gone forth, their spiritual companions advise and instruct them:
translation_text.mn67:16.6: ‘You should go out like this, and come back like that. You should look to the front like this, and to the side like that. You should contract your limbs like this, and extend them like that. This is how you should bear your outer robe, bowl, and robes.’
translation_text.mn67:16.8: ‘Formerly, as laypeople, we advised and instructed others.
translation_text.mn67:16.9: And now these mendicants—who you’d think were our children or grandchildren—imagine they can advise and instruct us!’
translation_text.mn67:16.10: They resign the training and return to a lesser life.
translation_text.mn67:16.11: This is called a mendicant who resigns the training and returns to a lesser life for fear of the danger of waves.
translation_text.mn67:16.12: ‘Danger of waves’ is a term for anger and distress.
translation_text.mn67:17.1: And what, mendicants, is the danger of gharials?
translation_text.mn67:17.2: It’s when a gentleman has gone forth out of faith from the lay life to homelessness, thinking:
translation_text.mn67:17.3: ‘I’m swamped by rebirth, old age, and death; by sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. I’m swamped by suffering, mired in suffering.
translation_text.mn67:17.4: Hopefully I can make an end to this entire mass of suffering.’
translation_text.mn67:17.5: When they’ve gone forth, their spiritual companions advise and instruct them:
translation_text.mn67:17.6: ‘You may eat, consume, taste, and drink these things, but not those. You may eat what’s allowable, but not what’s unallowable. You may eat at the right time, but not at the wrong time.’
translation_text.mn67:17.7: They think: ‘Formerly, as laypeople, we used to eat, consume, taste, and drink what we wanted, not what we didn’t want.
translation_text.mn67:17.8: We ate and drank both allowable and unallowable things, at the right time and the wrong time.
translation_text.mn67:17.9: And these faithful householders give us delicious fresh and cooked foods at the wrong time of day. But these guys imagine they can gag our mouths!’
translation_text.mn67:17.10: They resign the training and return to a lesser life.
translation_text.mn67:17.11: This is called one who disavows the training and returns to a lesser life because they’re afraid of the danger of gharials.
translation_text.mn67:17.12: ‘Danger of gharials’ is a term for gluttony.
translation_text.mn67:18.1: And what, mendicants, is the danger of whirlpools?
translation_text.mn67:18.2: It’s when a gentleman has gone forth out of faith from the lay life to homelessness, thinking:
translation_text.mn67:18.3: ‘I’m swamped by rebirth, old age, and death; by sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. I’m swamped by suffering, mired in suffering.
translation_text.mn67:18.4: Hopefully I can make an end to this entire mass of suffering.’
translation_text.mn67:18.5: When they’ve gone forth, they robe up in the morning and, taking their bowl and robe, enter a village or town for alms without guarding body, speech, and mind, without establishing mindfulness, and without restraining the sense faculties.
translation_text.mn67:18.6: There they see a householder or their child amusing themselves, supplied and provided with the five kinds of sensual stimulation.
translation_text.mn67:18.8: ‘Formerly, as laypeople, we amused ourselves, supplied and provided with the five kinds of sensual stimulation.
translation_text.mn67:18.9: And it’s true that my family is wealthy.
translation_text.mn67:18.10: I can both enjoy my wealth and make merit.’
translation_text.mn67:18.11: They resign the training and return to a lesser life.
translation_text.mn67:18.12: This is called one who disavows the training and returns to a lesser life for fear of the danger of whirlpools.
translation_text.mn67:18.13: ‘Danger of whirlpools’ is a term for the five kinds of sensual stimulation.
translation_text.mn67:19.1: And what, mendicants, is the danger of sharks?
translation_text.mn67:19.2: It’s when a gentleman has gone forth out of faith from the lay life to homelessness, thinking:
translation_text.mn67:19.3: ‘I’m swamped by rebirth, old age, and death; by sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. I’m swamped by suffering, mired in suffering.
translation_text.mn67:19.4: Hopefully I can make an end to this entire mass of suffering.’
translation_text.mn67:19.5: When they’ve gone forth, they robe up in the morning and, taking their bowl and robe, enter a village or town for alms without guarding body, speech, and mind, without establishing mindfulness, and without restraining the sense faculties.
translation_text.mn67:19.6: There they see a lady scantily clad, with revealing clothes.
translation_text.mn67:19.8: so they resign the training and return to a lesser life.
translation_text.mn67:19.9: This is called one who disavows the training and returns to a lesser life for fear of the danger of sharks.
translation_text.mn67:19.10: ‘Danger of sharks’ is a term for ladies.
translation_text.mn67:20.1: These are the four dangers that an individual who gone forth from the lay life to homelessness in this teaching and training should anticipate.”
translation_text.mn67:20.2: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.mn67:20.3: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.

variant_text.mn67:18.9: Saṁvijjanti kho pana me kule → saṁvijjante kho kule (bj, sya-all, km, pts1ed)
